Lets understand figsize.

Matplotlib Figsize is a method from the pyplot class which allows you to change the dimensions of the graph. As every dimension in generated graphs is adjusted by the library, it can be quite difficult to visualize data in a improper format. As a result, the figsize method is very useful to customize the dimensions as well as layouts of the graphs. 

We can make the figure taller in size, broader by changing the size in inches.  As seen above we set the figure size to 3 * 3. Lets plot and see the actual size visually.

So the first thing we have to do is import matplotlib, which we already did. We do this with the line, `import matplotlib.pyplot as plt`.

We then create a variable `fig`, and set it equal to, `plt.figure()`

This creates a figure object, which of course is initially empty, because we haven't populated it with anything.

So we have a figure object stored in the variable, fig, that is empty.

To show this empty figure object, we use the line, `plt.show()` or `fig.show()`.

We are using `%matplotlib inline` : This line allows the figure of a graph to be shown with jupyter notebooks.

After running the following code above, we get the following empty figure with default size (The default width is 6, and The default height is 4). Indeed we could change the size, using `figsize`.

In Matplotlib all the diagrams are created at a default size of 6.4 x 4.8 inches (refer https://matplotlib.org/stable/api/_as_gen/matplotlib.pyplot.figure.html) . This size can be changed by using the Figsize method of the respective figure. This parameter is governed under the rcParams attribute of the figure. By using Figsize, you can change both of these values.

Of course there is nothing in the figure, because we haven't written any code that populates the figure.

But we will do this soon, keep reading.

And this is how to create an empty figure object with matplotlib with Python.
